maml:description.maml:para: Compares Automate Online Status with Control, and outputs all machines online in Control and not in Automate
Compares Automate Online Status with Control, and outputs all machines online in Control and not in Automate
Can be taken from the pipeline in the form of Get-AutomateComputer -ComputerID 5 | Compare-AutomateControlStatus
Instead of outputting a comparison it outputs everything, which include two columns indicating online status
Doesn't output any log messages
Can be taken from the pipeline in the form of Get-AutomateComputer -ComputerID 5 | Compare-AutomateControlStatus
Instead of outputting a comparison it outputs everything, which include two columns indicating online status
Doesn't output any log messages

dev:type.maml:name: An object containing Online status for Control and Automate

Version: 1.4 Author: Gavin Stone Creation Date: 20/01/2019 Purpose/Change: Initial script development

Update Date: 2019-06-24 Author: Darren White Purpose/Change: Update to use objects returned by Get-ControlSessions

maml:description.maml:para: Connect to the Automate API.
Connects to the Automate API and returns a bearer token which when passed with each requests grants up to an hours worth of access.
The address to your Automate Server. Example 'rancor.hostedrmm.com'
Used internally when quietly refreshing the Token
Used internally when quietly refreshing the Token
Will not output any standard messages. Returns $True if connection was successful.
The address to your Automate Server. Example 'rancor.hostedrmm.com'
Used internally when quietly refreshing the Token
Takes a string that represents the 2FA number
Will not attempt to refresh a current session
Will not output any standard messages. Returns $True if connection was successful.
The address to your Automate Server. Example 'rancor.hostedrmm.com'
Used internally when quietly refreshing the Token
Specifies to test the current token, and if it is not valid attempt to obtain a new one using the current credentials. Does not refresh (re-issue) the current token.
Will not output any standard messages. Returns $True if connection was successful.
The address to your Automate Server. Example 'rancor.hostedrmm.com'
Used internally when quietly refreshing the Token
Used internally when quietly refreshing the Token
Will not output any standard messages. Returns $True if connection was successful.
Takes a string that represents the 2FA number
Will not attempt to refresh a current session
Specifies to test the current token, and if it is not valid attempt to obtain a new one using the current credentials. Does not refresh (re-issue) the current token.

dev:type.maml:name: Three strings into Script variables, $CWAServer containing the server address, $CWACredentials containing the bearer token and $CWACredentialsExpirationDate containing the date the credentials expire

maml:alert.maml:para:
Version: 1.1 Author: Gavin Stone Creation Date: 2019-01-20 Purpose/Change: Initial script development
Update Date: 2019-02-12 Author: Darren White Purpose/Change: Credential and 2FA prompting is only if needed. Supports Token Refresh.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds credentials required to connect to the Control API

Creates a Control hashtable in memory containing the server and username/password so that it can be used in other functions that connect to ConnectWise Control. Unfortunately the Control API does not support 2FA.
Takes a standard powershell credential object, this can be built with $CredentialsToPass = Get-Credential, then pass $CredentialsToPass
The address to your Control Server. Example 'https://control.rancorthebeast.com:8040'
Used to set Server URL and Credentials without testing.
Will not output any standard logging messages. Function will returns True or False.
The address to your Control Server. Example 'https://control.rancorthebeast.com:8040'
Automate APIKey for Control Extension
Used to set Server URL and Credentials without testing.
Will not output any standard logging messages. Function will returns True or False.
Attempt to verify Cached API key or Credentials. Invalid results will be removed.
Will not output any standard logging messages. Function will returns True or False.
Takes a standard powershell credential object, this can be built with $CredentialsToPass = Get-Credential, then pass $CredentialsToPass
The address to your Control Server. Example 'https://control.rancorthebeast.com:8040'
Used to set Server URL and Credentials without testing.
Will not output any standard logging messages. Function will returns True or False.
Automate APIKey for Control Extension
Attempt to verify Cached API key or Credentials. Invalid results will be removed.

dev:type.maml:name: Sets script variables with Server URL and Credentials or ApiKey.

maml:alert.maml:para:
Version: 1.0 Author: Gavin Stone Creation Date: 20/01/2019 Purpose/Change: Initial script development
Version: 1.1 Author: Gavin Stone Creation Date: 22/06/2019 Purpose/Change: The previous function was far too complex. No-one could debug it and a lot of it was unnecessary. I have greatly simplified it.
Version: 1.2 Author: Darren White Creation Date: 2019-06-24 Purpose/Change: Added support for APIKey authentication. The new function was not complex enough.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: All values will be prompted for one by one:

dev:remarks.maml:para: Connect-ControlAPI All values needed to Automatically create appropriate output Connect-ControlAPI -Server "https://control.rancorthebeast.com:8040" -Credentials $CredentialsToPass

maml:description.maml:para: Internal function used to make generic API calls
Internal function used to make generic API calls
The page size of the results that come back from the API - limit this when needed
Brings back a particular page as defined
The individial URI to post to for results, IE computers?
Order by - Used to sort the results by a field. Can be sorted in ascending or descending order. Example - fieldname asc Example - fieldname desc

Condition - the searches that can be used to search for specific things. Supported operators are '=', 'eq', '>', '>=', '<', '<=', 'and', 'or', '()', 'like', 'contains', 'in', 'not'. The 'not' operator is only used with 'in', 'like', or 'contains'. The '=' and 'eq' operator are the same. String values can be surrounded with either single or double quotes. Boolean values are specified as 'true' or 'false'. Parenthesis can be used to control the order of operations and group conditions. The 'like' operator translates to the MySQL 'like' operator.
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified only these fields will be included in the result set
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified these fields will be excluded from the final result set
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified only these IDs will be returned
Will bring back all results for a particular query with no concern for result set size
The individial URI to post to for results, IE computers?
Order by - Used to sort the results by a field. Can be sorted in ascending or descending order. Example - fieldname asc Example - fieldname desc

Condition - the searches that can be used to search for specific things. Supported operators are '=', 'eq', '>', '>=', '<', '<=', 'and', 'or', '()', 'like', 'contains', 'in', 'not'. The 'not' operator is only used with 'in', 'like', or 'contains'. The '=' and 'eq' operator are the same. String values can be surrounded with either single or double quotes. Boolean values are specified as 'true' or 'false'. Parenthesis can be used to control the order of operations and group conditions. The 'like' operator translates to the MySQL 'like' operator.
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified only these fields will be included in the result set
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified these fields will be excluded from the final result set
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified only these IDs will be returned
The page size of the results that come back from the API - limit this when needed
Brings back a particular page as defined
The individial URI to post to for results, IE computers?

The 'not' operator is only used with 'in', 'like', or 'contains'. The '=' and 'eq' operator are the same. String values can be surrounded with either single or double quotes. Boolean values are specified as 'true' or 'false'. Parenthesis can be used to control the order of operations and group conditions. The 'like' operator translates to the MySQL 'like' operator.
A comma delimited list of fields, when specified only these fields will be included in the result set

maml:alert.maml:para: Version: 1.0 Author: Gavin Stone Creation Date: 20/01/2019 Purpose/Change: Initial script development

maml:description.maml:para: Get Client information out of the Automate API
Connects to the Automate API and returns one or more full client objects
ClientID to search for, integer, -ClientID 1
Returns all clients in Automate, regardless of amount
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.

A custom condition to build searches that can be used to search for specific things. Supported operators are '=', 'eq', '>', '>=', '<', '<=', 'and', 'or', '()', 'like', 'contains', 'in', 'not'. The 'not' operator is only used with 'in', 'like', or 'contains'. The '=' and 'eq' operator are the same. String values can be surrounded with either single or double quotes. IE (RemoteAgentLastContact <= 2019-12-18T00:50:19.575Z) Boolean values are specified as 'true' or 'false'. Parenthesis can be used to control the order of operations and group conditions.
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.
Client name to search for, uses wildcards so full client name is not needed
LocationID to search for, integer, -LocationID 2
Location name to search for, uses wildcards so full location name is not needed
ClientID to search for, integer, -ClientID 1
Returns all clients in Automate, regardless of amount
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.

A custom condition to build searches that can be used to search for specific things. Supported operators are '=', 'eq', '>', '>=', '<', '<=', 'and', 'or', '()', 'like', 'contains', 'in', 'not'. The 'not' operator is only used with 'in', 'like', or 'contains'. The '=' and 'eq' operator are the same. String values can be surrounded with either single or double quotes. IE (RemoteAgentLastContact <= 2019-12-18T00:50:19.575Z) Boolean values are specified as 'true' or 'false'. Parenthesis can be used to control the order of operations and group conditions.
Client name to search for, uses wildcards so full client name is not needed
LocationID to search for, integer, -LocationID 2
Location name to search for, uses wildcards so full location name is not needed

maml:alert.maml:para: Version: 1.0 Author: Gavin Stone and Andrea Mastellone Creation Date: 2019-03-19 Purpose/Change: Initial script development

maml:description.maml:para: Get Computer information out of the Automate API
Connects to the Automate API and returns one or more full computer objects
Can take either single ComputerID integer, IE 1, or an array of ComputerID integers, IE 1,5,9
Returns all computers in Automate, regardless of amount
A comma separated list of fields that you want including in the returned computer object.
A comma separated list of fields that you want excluding in the returned computer object.
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.

A custom condition to build searches that can be used to search for specific things. Supported operators are '=', 'eq', '>', '>=', '<', '<=', 'and', 'or', '()', 'like', 'contains', 'in', 'not'. The 'not' operator is only used with 'in', 'like', or 'contains'. The '=' and 'eq' operator are the same. String values can be surrounded with either single or double quotes. IE (RemoteAgentLastContact <= 2019-12-18T00:50:19.575Z) Boolean values are specified as 'true' or 'false'. Parenthesis can be used to control the order of operations and group conditions.
A comma separated list of fields that you want including in the returned computer object.
A comma separated list of fields that you want excluding in the returned computer object.
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.
A comma separated list of fields that you want including in the returned computer object.
A comma separated list of fields that you want excluding in the returned computer object.
A comma separated list of fields that you want to order by finishing with either an asc or desc.
Client name to search for, uses wildcards so full client name is not needed
ClientID to search for, integer, -ClientID 1
LocationID to search for, integer, -LocationID 2
Location name to search for, uses wildcards so full location name is not needed
Computer name to search for, uses wildcards so full computer name is not needed
Searches through all computers and finds where a UDP or TCP port is open. Can either take a single number, ie -OpenPort "443"
Operating system name to search for, uses wildcards so full OS Name not needed. IE: -OperatingSystem "Windows 7"
Domain name to search for, uses wildcards so full OS Name not needed. IE: -DomainName ".local"
Returns all computers that have not been seen in an amount of days. IE: -NotSeenInDays 30
Returns all computers that have a comment set with the computer in Automate. Wildcard search.
Returns computers where the LastWindowUpdate in days is over a certain amount. This is not based on patch manager information but information in Windows
Returns computers where the Antivirus definitions are older than x days
Returns computers with a specific local IP address
Returns the external IP of the Computer
Returns computers with an mac address as a wildcard search
Returns computers with a certain logged in user, using wildcard search, IE: -LoggedInUser "Gavin" will find all computers where a Gavin is logged in.
Returns computers that are Automate masters
Returns computers that are Automate network probes
Returns agents that are affected by the Automate Binary issue hitting on 9th March 2019
Returns agents that are online or offline, IE -Online $true or alternatively -Online $false
Takes an integer in minutes and brings back all users who have been idle on their machines longer than that. IE -UserIdleLongerThanMinutes 60
Takes an integer in minutes and brings back all computers that have an uptime longer than x minutes. IE -UptimeLongerThanMinutes 60
Return computers with a certain asset tag - a wildcard search
Return computers that are servers, boolean value can be used as -Server $true or -Server $false
Return computers that are workstations, boolean value can be used as -Workstation $true or -Workstation $false
Return computers that have a certain antivirus. Wildcard search.
Return computers that need a reboot. Bool. -RebootNeeded $true or -RebootNeeded $false
Return computers that are virtual hosts. Bool. -VirtualHost $true or -VirtualHost $false
Return computers that have a serial number specified. Wildcard Search
Return computers with a specific Bios Manufacturer. Wildcard search.
Return computers with a specific BIOS Version. This is a string search and a wildcard.
Return computers where certain local user accounts are present
Can take either single ComputerID integer, IE 1, or an array of ComputerID integers, IE 1,5,9

Defaults to "$($env:USERPROFILE)\AutomateAPI\" to fetch credentials
When specified, fetches credentials from disk and loads them into the variables necessary for Automate related cmdlets to function
Overrides default credential folder path

maml:alert.maml:para: Does not return a credential object! You do not need to run Connect-AutomateAPI or Connect-ControlAPI, this method calls those methods to validate the credentials To prevent reconnection each time, you will want to store the connection state yourself as shown in the above example

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Will issue a command against a given machine and return the results.
Will issue a command against a given machine and return the results.

The GUID identifier for the machine you wish to connect to. You can retrieve session info with the 'Get-ControlSessions' commandlet SessionIDs can be provided via the pipeline. IE - Get-AutomateComputer -ComputerID 5 | Get-ControlSessions | Invoke-ControlCommand -Powershell -Command "Get-Service"
The command you wish to issue to the machine.
The amount of time in milliseconds that a command can execute. The default is 10000 milliseconds.
The maximum number of bytes to return from the remote session. The default is 5000 bytes.
Number of control sessions to invoke commands in parallel.
Issues the command in a powershell session.

The GUID identifier for the machine you wish to connect to. You can retrieve session info with the 'Get-ControlSessions' commandlet SessionIDs can be provided via the pipeline. IE - Get-AutomateComputer -ComputerID 5 | Get-ControlSessions | Invoke-ControlCommand -Powershell -Command "Get-Service"
The command you wish to issue to the machine.
The amount of time in milliseconds that a command can execute. The default is 10000 milliseconds.
The maximum number of bytes to return from the remote session. The default is 5000 bytes.
Issues the command in a powershell session.
Number of control sessions to invoke commands in parallel.

dev:type.maml:name: The output of the Command provided.

maml:alert.maml:para:
Version: 2.2 Author: Chris Taylor Modified By: Gavin Stone Modified By: Darren White Creation Date: 1/20/2016 Purpose/Change: Initial script development
Update Date: 2019-02-19 Author: Darren White Purpose/Change: Enable Pipeline support. Enable processing using Automate Control Extension. The cached APIKey will be used if present.
Update Date: 2019-02-23 Author: Darren White Purpose/Change: Enable command batching against multiple sessions. Added OfflineAction parameter.
Update Date: 2019-06-24 Author: Darren White Purpose/Change: Updates to process object returned by Get-ControlSessions

dev:remarks.maml:para: Will retrieve Computer Information from Automate, Get ControlSession data and merge with the input object, then call Get-Service on the computer.
Will return the hostname of the machine.
Will restart the Automate agent on the target machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Takes changed detected in Compare-AutomateControlStatus and performs a specified repair on them
Takes changed detected in Compare-AutomateControlStatus and performs a specified repair on them
Takes either Update, Restart, Reinstall or Check
When multiple jobs are run, they run in Parallel. Batch size determines how many jobs can run at once. Default is 10
If you do not wish to use the LT Posh module on GitHub you can use your own link to the LTPosh Module with this parameter
Object taken from the Pipeline from Compare-AutomateControlStatus
Takes either Update, Restart, Reinstall or Check
When multiple jobs are run, they run in Parallel. Batch size determines how many jobs can run at once. Default is 10
If you do not wish to use the LT Posh module on GitHub you can use your own link to the LTPosh Module with this parameter
Object taken from the Pipeline from Compare-AutomateControlStatus
Sets credential objects on a server that has never had them before
This function takes a Powershell script and sets credentials on the local disk encrypted with the local system
Will save both Automate and Control credentials
Will save both Automate and Control credentials
